text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with a classic simple garlic aioli
which is redundant since aioli means
basically garlic and oil this version
was inspired by Michael Symon Iron Chef
Michael Symon at a demo I saw in Aspen
it requires no equipment no mortar and
pestle no blender no nothing here we go
we're going to take one large garlic
clove I'm going to cut that root end off
it's kind of you know hard and tough and
I don't like to smash in with the
regular garlic take the flat of your
knife smash the clove remove the paper
all right and during the demo Michael
Symon made it clear he's not a big fan
of garlic presses because he doesn't
like to clean them which I can relate to
and you know I use my garlic press a lot
but this method also works great so what
you want to do is once you smash it with
the flat of the knife you're going to
chop it up until it looks sort of like
that and then add a nice pinch of salt
coarse kosher salt or sea salt and then
when the flat of your knife just keep
crushing it pressing it squeezing it and
just mashing it against the board until
it's like a puree very simple and why
you want to use a coarse salt is the
crystals will actually help mash the
garlic and that really gets all the
flavor out of the garlic we're going to
add one egg yolk one raw egg yolk about
two teaspoons of lemon juice and then
we're going to whisk in a half a cup of
oil but before we do I want you to make
a little ring a little horseshoe with
two or three pieces of wet paper towel
that will keep your bowl just off the
board and you will only need one hand to
whisk and one hand to pour the oil and
the you know the bowl won't be moving
all over now when you start off you're
going to take your half cup of olive oil
I'm using a nice extra virgin you're
going to just drip in drip in the first
tablespoon a drip at a time and will
start to emulsify see that it's nice and
foamy it starts to thicken up a little
once it gets that little bit of thick
consistency you can pretty much drizzle
it in in a steady stream so just be
careful with the first tablespoon and
the rest of it you can just kind of drip
in the thicker it gets the faster you
can drip the faster you drip the thicker
it gets and so on all right so we're
going
add in a half a cup of extra virgin
olive oil to our one egg yolk if you
want to add more than one clove of
garlic you can but you're going to be
amazed at how strong one clove of garlic
when you crushed against the board like
that makes this aioli and by the way
aioli
probably the greatest sauce ever
invented everything is great with aioli
this is the ultimate sandwich spread a
teaspoon of this in any salad dressing
just makes it killer is a condiment to
any grilled meat awesome and dipping
vegetables if I was a vegetable and I've
thought about what it would be like if I
was a vegetable I would love love to be
dipped in tailee so there you go the 1/2
cup has been drizzled in we have that
beautiful thick mayonnaise consistency
and a li best described as simply a
garlic mayonnaise nothing complicated
here all right there you go so I had
enough salt in my pinch I put with the
garlic but you want to taste this I
didn't put pepper some people put black
pepper and all kinds of herbs and things
this is just the basic mix it will keep
for a couple weeks in your fridge but
you know what why are you waiting two
weeks to use this you make it half a cup
of this little ramekin like that you
should be using that within a week it's
so delicious coming up we're going to
have another demo where I'm going to
take this and use it to make the world's
greatest garlic bread that's right
secret recipe coming soon anyway give it
a try go to the site all the ingredients
are there and as always enjoy
